pages.title: Week 1 - Quick Intro to Web Development

elements.content: [[b]]Front End: [[/]] functionality on the side of the client (HTML/CSS/JS)
ex. (Video Game - graphic framework draws the player's avatar and accepts user input)
[[b]]Back End: [[/]] functionality on the side of the server (PHP, Node.js, SQL, etc.)
ex. (Video Game - keeps track of the map, hp bars, player locations, player damage, etc.)
[[h3]]Purpose of HTML[[/]]
Stands for: [[b]]H[[/]]yper [[b]]T[[/]]ext [[b]]M[[/]]arkup [[b]]L[[/]]anguage
HTML designs the layout of text and structure of the web page.
Formats content (images, videos, external links, etc.)
[[h3]]Things to keep in mind[[/]]
➔ Forgiving for wrong syntax, errors, and missing information (code can still contain errors)
➔ Semantics/structure (for readability, web crawlers, SEO, etc.) - use proper tags and divisions
➔ May render depending on browser/device (test pages on multiple browsers)
➔ Separate presentation and content (HTML mainly for structure and CSS for style)
[[h3]]Setting up Repl[[/]]
➔ Go to replit.com and make a new account by using either email or a social account
➔ Once you make a new account, click the new repl button, and make a HTML, CSS, JS repl
➔ Once you have your repl, you can start putting all your code in there

pages.title: Week 1 - Anatomy of an HTML document

elements.content: ➔ Doctype: remnant of an old HTML practice, tells the browser what version of HTML we are using (default HTML5 is [[monospace]]<!DOCTYPE html>[[/]])
➔ html: Wraps all other content, sometimes called the root element
➔ Head: Container for everything that isn’t displayed as content
[[b]]➔ Head: includes metadata such as the title, scripts, charset, styles, etc.[[/]]
[[ ]]◆ Meta charset: what character set you are using. utf-8 includes most human language characters
[[ ]]◆ title: Sets the title of the page on the browser tab
[[b]]➔ Body: Contains all content that is displayed on the page[[/]]
[[h3]]Headings[[/]]
➔ Define the heading of a section or page
➔ Can use 6 heading tags (pick the correct heading; ex. don’t use all [[monospace]]<h1>[[/]] tags and lower the font size later)
➔ [[monospace]]<h1>[[/]] tags for main headings of a page or article
➔ Practice: Add an [[monospace]]<h1>[[/]] tag to your page with any heading you want
[[h3]]Paragraphs[[/]]

➔ Add bodies of text by using the [[monospace]]

[[/]] tag
➔ Separate paragraphs with a good structure - keep a cleaner website and improve SEO

➔ Break ([[monospace]]
[[/]]) tag to add line breaks within your paragraph
➔ Practice: Add a paragraph after your [[monospace]]<h1>[[/]] tag with any text you want, put a line break, and add another paragraph with new text
[[h3]]Divisions (divs)[[/]]
➔ Generic container tag [[monospace]]<div>[[/]] for grouping HTML tags
➔ Used mainly to apply CSS to the enclosed tags
➔ Does not affect the webpage besides creating a line break before the division
➔ Use [[monospace]]<section>[[/]] instead of [[monospace]]<div>[[/]] if you want to give semantic meaning (i.e. group similar things together more properly as a “section”)
➔ Practice: Group your hyperlinks using the [[monospace]]<div>[[/]] tag (applying CSS will be discussed next week)
[[h3]]Attributes[[/]]
➔ Attributes have a basic syntax of attribute=value
➔ Space between the tag name and the attribute name
➔ Single or double quotes based on your own preference
➔ Used for setting certain characteristics or using CSS/Javascript
➔ Practice: Make an h1 tag with the attribute id equal to top and a p tag with attribute class equal to bottom.

elements.content: [[h3]]Images[[/]]
➔ Can add images from all kinds of sources including URLs and local files
➔ Display images on a webpage with [[monospace]][[/]]
➔ There are two main attributes
[[ ]]◆ [[monospace]]src[[/]] specifies the location of the image to be used
[[ ]]◆ [[monospace]]alt[[/]] specifies some text that represents the image (for blind people and website parsers)
➔ Practice: Add an image (from URL or from your project) and create alternative text for it
[[h3]]Hyperlinks[[/]]
➔ Clickable lines of text to add in a website to redirect the user to another page or website
➔ Use the anchor ([[monospace]][[/]]) tag to add hyperlinks
➔ Main attribute([[monospace]]href[[/]] tag ) that specifies the URL of the redirect
➔ Practice: Wrap a word or two in your paragraph with [[monospace]][[/]] and add the href attribute to any link you want!
[[h3]]Ordered List[[/]]
➔ Numbered with a 1, 2, 3 etc.
➔ Text on each list item or any other item of your choice including images

➔ Syntax: insert [[monospace]]
    [[/]] tags and add [[monospace]]
  1. [[/]] for each list item
➔ Type attributes [[monospace]](“1”, “I”, “i”, “A”, “a”)[[/]]
➔ Practice: Add an ordered list to your webpage with three elements (ex. top 3 favorite movies, books, etc.)
[[h3]]Unordered List[[/]]
➔ Lists for items whose order doesn’t matter and uses bullet points
➔ Can have text on each list item or any other item of your choice including images

➔ Syntax includes starting with [[monospace]]
    [[/]] tags and adding
  • for every list item
➔ Type attributes ([[monospace]]“disc”, “circle”, “square”, “none”[[/]])
➔ Practice: Add an unordered list to your webpage with three elements that don’t have a specific order(ex. colors, locations, etc.)
